Courageous follows five men and their families. It shows the struggles that each of the men have as they try to lead their families, and lead their families as the spiritual and moral compass of the family. Courageous also deals with the issue of social class and the difficulty of a poor immigrant family surviving in a new country. It shows the barriers that Javier must overcome to get a job because he does not posses a higher education. The movie also showcases the effect of divorce on a family, which can either be seen in a positive or negative light, because there were economic hardships tied to being divorced but also the possibility of a better relationship between Shane and his ex-wife because of a less tenuous relationship that would have affected his son negatively.

Grab a box of tissues, a snack, and sit back to watch a movie that'll change your life in my opinion, so much that you'll never be the same. Courageous is the story of four policemen who are also after a time, four brothers in the Lord. The Police scenes are all very realistic (and I am one who once spent a lot of time around a police station working where I did.) and some scenes will have you hanging on to your seat! There are happy moments, very sad moments (thus the tissues!), lots of drama both as Policemen in uniform and at home with their families. Along the way, a 'handy man' named Harvee' becomes "adopted by their group" as character Adam Mitchell played by Alex Kendrick, one of the movie's writers, put it, after being hired to help Adam (Kendrick) build a garage as he is praying for work and Adam is actually waiting for a handyman referred to him by his fellow officer/best friend Shane - named Harvey! A VERY funny scene where Harvey is working on the garage when the guys are out for lunch and Shane reveals that his friend Harvey is in the hospital! Same name - different Harvey, another funny scene that goes into the saddest scene of the film. (which I won't give away)  After the mix up though, they become good friends and Harvey begins a full time job that Adam referred him for and the test given him is one given to many in real life, yet as the actors say, few can seem to pass it. You find yourself cheering Harvey's character on throughout the movie for his job searching, deep faith, and his portrayl of one the "Street Kings." (prepare for a laugh until you cry moment!) Personally,that's one of my favorite scenes! Many poignant family moments combined with police on the job action and a main storyline woven in as smoothly as silk with a message so powerful about fathers and family that your own life may be changed in that area. Many scenes in this movie softens hearts and for me anyway, gave me the desire to be the best woman/Christian/wife/mother I can possibly be. I've seen amazing changes in my husband, and that's seldom seen just from seeing a movie but - the message of being the BEST father and husband that leads his home by the Word of God Courageous is SO very powerful and makes you feel every emotion you possibly feel. Whether Christian or not, I HIGHLY recommend Courageous. My husband and I watch our copy at least twice a week, it's THAT good. Best news is, it has so many powerful scenes that while watching with several non-Christians, two gave their lives to Christ after seeing it with us! Whether a couple in their 50s with children and grandchildren like us, or a Church group - young or old, I just cannot recommend Couragous more! I PRAY that the Kendrick brothers actually read these reviews, as we would LOVE to see MANY MORE movies written/made by them. Lots of talent, both in storylines and in acting. Actors & actresses chosen completely fit the parts and this also is the same with their other films: their first, Flywheel, also Facing the Giants (watching as I type this!) and Fireproof. ALL wonderful in their own ways. We HAD to own them all! You'll NOT be sorry viewing and purchasing this gem, whether Christian or non. Thank you, Kendrick brothers, for wonderful family entertainment - Christian or non - Courageous with a message that touches hearts and leaves us craving much more!  A MUST SEE! For us, 5 stars isn't enough, it's THAT good! Many fathers, especially Christian fathers, will have a difficult time remaining seated in the final scene, when Adam is speaking at church about dads and their being Godly and Courageous dads, husbands, and men during the call for such dads who are among those the most courageous for God and family. By the way -- ALL the actors are members of a Sherwood Church in Albany,Georgia. I think that's AMAZING! (I pray that the town is correct - I forget the denomination of the church, but all the actors are members of that church, also all their movies are made with ONE camera - this is info from one of the extras parts of the DVD - and to me that's far MORE than just another amazing blessing!)

The first of the Kendricks' movies that our family has seen, and it remains one of the best: it will hold the interest and be instructive to kids from 8 or 9 through adulthood.  From start to finish, it is loaded with various examples of courageous actions, and includes several other examples of how it's best not to put off good actions today, relying on a tomorrow which might just not arrive.  The movies starts off with a bang in a typical Hollywood style action scene depicting strong physical courage, but inserts an unusual twist causing the viewer to reevaluate how s/he may have started judging the protagonist's actions. Then it proceeds at a never before seen pace, presenting a series of other events involving how different kinds of courage are needed.  One person is challenged to provide for his family in the face of strong odds. Some face moral dilemmas calling for a new kind of courage; moral courage in the face of peer pressure; keeping their sanity and family together by practicing a quiet resolute courage to face a horrible reality and build from there...

We loved this movie so much that we've shown it to our extended families and used it as a model to discuss several themes as they might pertain to daily life.  One of the movie's great strengths was also an area where I found my only quibble; the importance of men providing strong male role models for their families.  Some men were able to provide good, effective support to their families; some men failed; and some just had to try again, step by step. The quibbles I had with this movie showing a high reliance on formal ritual seemed over the top to me, but were extremely minor, and perhaps some will find them more or less irritating than I did.

But taken as a whole, this is one of the best - perhaps THE best family movie ever made.  Powerful, exciting, thought provoking, humorous, and filled with topics worth discussing at every level of life.

Four Police Officers and their families, plus the humorous bonus of a new-comer to their already, brave and elite group. Steady employment, loving wives, children and fatherhood. Wait a minute? Fatherhood? You know, that title which dad's are supposed to be filling?! The unique and individual role of loving, steady leadership and an example for their children to look up too, and be proud of? Oh yes..., that fatherhood. Remember? Hmm...? In today's day and time, how exactly is it defined? "I bring home the main bacon. My wife gets the check. And there is food on the table. Now, will you please leave me alone and let me watch the ballgame?" Relationship? "I married you, didn't I?" Relationship with the kids? "They have a roof over their head with all of the toy's - TV's, stereo's, computers, headsets and a mobile phone. So, back off and  let me drink my beer and watch the ballgame in peace!?" Relationship? "Have the kids do it. I'm busy!" Family outing's and quality time spent together? "I told you..., I'm meeting with the guys, down at the pool hall." Fatherhood? "Yeah, that's my kid, what of it?" Relationship? "I think they're out someplace with their friends?" Role model? "I don't care. Ask your mother." Fatherhood, relationship and a steady and stable, paternal, role model. Has fatherhood truly been, redefined? Is it a 'thing' of the past? Is it understood that husbands and father's are indifferent to their wives and children, even when they are physically in the house? Is showing steadfast integrity, strong and loving leadership, merciful discipline, spending quality time together with ones wife and children and standing up for ones morals, principles, scruples and even - faith, especially if it goes against the social grain, something that you only read about? How being a good husband and father, 'used to be?' Fathers - don't tell your children to do things alone rather, do it with them. As a mentor, a parental role model who sets an example, with love and an encouraging teaching attitude. Don't just brush them off as if, being with your children is some arduous chore. A duty that you feel obligated too, but dread. Have a relationship with your wife and children while you can, because there are so many men that don't have that privilege or pleasure, anymore. Death, divorce and child custody suits, are on the rise. Does 'being there for your kids', sound like something for the movies, to you? It doesn't have to be. COURAGEOUS! Do you dare..., dad? In color, on a single, DVD-disc, this film comes with a message of faith, hope, example and love..., too husbands, father's and exhortation, for the whole family. A keeper for your DVD collection that you may need to end up watching, over and over and over. Why? As a refresher course, if anything.... Nina Kish

This movie should be a must see by every father in America!  It is the story of four men, who after the tragic death of the daughter of one of the men, take a pledge to become better fathers.  Ridden with guilt after his daughter's death, a police officer takes stock of himself and realizes that he never spent the time he should have with his daughter.  He always had something else to do or in the instance when she wanted him to dance in the park with her to her favorite song, he was afraid of the embarrassment he would feel if people saw him dancing with his daughter to no music.  Unable to live with his grief, he goes to his pastor for counseling.  He then gets his Bible out and searches scripture for what God says about being a father and spiritual head of the family.  He writes a Resolution which he prints out and gives to his pals to read and he asks them to make him accountable.  After reading the Resolution, the rest of the men decided they want to sign it too.  They each want to work at becoming better fathers.  At the signing ceremony the pastor warns them that there will be challenges ahead for them and there are many challenges but they help each other through those challenges.  This movie depicts strong family values, something that is lacking in this country right now.  We need more movies like this!
